comments.content:
College Black (outline)...from Casady and Greene.   
   
C&G went out of business earlier this year.

I wonder what happened to all the rights to C&G software.   
   
it's manually stretched a bit, btw   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516141057im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/18972.jpg)

I hope you don't mean their fonts. They were one of   
the first third-party PostScript font vendors. Their early   
success at selling fonts had more to do with the lack of   
choice than quality. They were pretty bad. Although they   
continued to sell them to the end, they stopped developing   
them long ago and went on to develop and market some   
very useful software--including what eventually became   
iTunes.

Mark, I checked out their bundled package and they do have   
quite a few specialty fonts that could prove useful for   
specific applications. I'll try to post a few that might be   
unique digitizations.   
   
Granted, viewed in its entirety, their type library is poor.   
And Conflict Catcher and several other apps   
never made the jump to OSX...

Gazelle was one of those C&G unique fonts. I had an SSI   
knockoff that I adored and Mike Y. ID'd the original as   
Gazelle. Sort of an Arthur Bakerishly calligraphic script.   
   
I bought it just in the nick of time, as it turned out. Some   
of the letter spacing could be better, but the character   
set is fairly complete.   
   
It seems like when I surveyed the font offerings on the   
website, a few of the scripts were the only faces that   
stood out as unique.   
   
(What was with that Fluent Laser Fonts moniker?)

Oops. My mistake. I was looking at faces such as   
Sedona Script and Aurora Grotesk thinking they were   
bundled C & G fonts when in fact they are bundled   
OPTI fonts.   
   
C & G has a very small library it now appears, with Jott,   
Dry Gulch and various other crud.   
   
 ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516141057im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)   
   
bj
